content:
From bitcoin-mining to freemasonry, and from Berlin to Finland, these were the blog’s most-read items

ON MOST DAYS we publish an explainer that adds context to a story in the news, or diverts readers with something more whimsical. This year our more newsy explainers have examined  birthright citizenship , Mark Zuckerberg testifying in Congress , Jacob Zuma’s resignation , the Netanyahu investigations , no-deal Brexit  and why tariffs are bad . But these, as with much news, had a shorter shelf-life than more evergreen pieces. The ten most-read explainers of the year were more esoteric. As the foundations of the liberal world order shake, it may be a relief to contemplate freemasonry  and happy Finns :

1.  How bitcoin mining works | January 2015

The most popular explainer of 2018 is not exactly fresh. Written nearly three years ago, it explained how bitcoin mining works and so gave a guide to a subject in which levels of interest remain high. (In July this year we explained “ Why bitcoin uses so much energy ”.) Bitcoin started 2018 at a price of $14,000, but is now wallowing around $3,000. When we explained how bitcoin mining worked, in January 2015, its price was $200.

2.  Why the war in Syria is hotting up | March 2018

As 2017 drew to a close it looked as though Syria’s seven-year war might be winding down. By March 2018 that hope looked misplaced, as the regime turned its guns on the rebels, Turkey sent troops over its border to battle Kurdish forces, and long-standing tensions between Iran and Israel flared. The collapse of Islamic State had been followed by a scramble for territory and widened fissures among foreign powers jostling for a say in Syria’s future. With the growing possibility of clashes between America and Turkey, and even America and Russia, Syria’s intractable war looked ever more impervious to peace.

3.  Why the current flu crisis is so severe | February 2018

The 2017-18 Flu season was a bad one. Flu or pneumonia had already killed over 50 children in America and were responsible for nearly 10% of all deaths in the week ending January 13th (thus exceeding the Centres for Disease Control and Prevention’s definition of an epidemic). Why so nasty? The dominant strain was the old but virulent H3N2 subtype, which is prone to the kind of rapid mutation that allows it to evade the defences the body created against previous variants. As a result, the Flu vaccine, developed early in 2017, has been less effective than usual. 

4.  Why there is a worldwide shortage of vanilla | March 2018

Vanilla is one of the world’s most popular spices and an important ingredient in products ranging from chocolate to perfume. But it is getting harder to find. Earlier in 2018 its wholesale price had reached $500-600 per kilogram, when just a few years ago it fetched a tenth of that. Madagascar used to supply around 80% of the world’s natural vanilla, but the market crashed in the 1980s as buyers turned their attention to the poorer-quality version available elsewhere. It was not until public tastes started shifting towards all things natural that Malagasy farmers’ fortunes revived. Demand surged, and with it prices—in part because vanilla vines take years to mature.

5.  What is freemasonry? | February 2018

Freemasonry grew out of medieval stonemasons’ guilds. In the 17th century, they began accepting non-stonemasons—men interested in mathematics and antiquity—and when guilds became obsolete these gentlemen enthusiasts made up the majority of members. Freemasonry survived as a network of groups, known as lodges, defined by a commitment to universal brotherhood and self-improvement. But because it had secretive and elaborate rituals, and because it is secular, non-partisan and based on enlightenment values, freemasonry has long drawn the ire of the Catholic church and right-wing politicians

6.  Why the Mediterranean will eventually disappear | August 2018

Fifty million years from now, the Mediterranean will close and Europe and Africa will merge to become one mega-continent: Eurafrica. The Mediterranean will be replaced by a mountain range as big as the Himalayas. This will be the result of the constant movement of tectonic plates underneath the Earth, dragged around by convection currents in the planet’s mantle. Scientists theorise that multiple super-continents have been created in cycles over the course of Earth’s history through the process of continental drift. 

7.  Why polygamy breeds civil war | March 2018

The 20 most fragile states in the world are all somewhat or very Polygamous. Polygamous nations are more likely to invade their neighbours and to have civil wars. This is because polygamy nearly always means that rich men take multiple wives, and the poorest are condemned to bachelorhood. Sexually frustrated and socially marginalised, young bachelors are more likely to resort to violence or stealing to secure a mate, and become easy recruits for rebel armies. One recent paper found that high brideprice is a “critical” factor “predisposing young men to become involved in organised group violence for political purposes”.

8.  Why is Finland so happy? | March 2018

In March 2018 Finland was named the happiest country in the world by the UN’s Sustainable Development Solutions Network. Three Nordic cousins—Norway, Denmark and Iceland—took the next places. The UN report uses global polling data from Gallup to measure how pleased people feel with their lives, and tries to explain the differences in results using variables such as GDP per person, social support, healthy-life expectancy, freedom to make life choices, generosity, and freedom from corruption. Its results suggest that happy societies are those with supportive social systems and institutions that make it harder for people to fall through the cracks.

9.  Why Berlin doesn’t work | January 2018

Without London, the average Briton would be 11.1% poorer. Without Paris, the French would be 14.8% poorer. But without Berlin, Germany’s GDP per person would actually rise by 0.2%. The capital of Europe’s biggest economy is surprisingly poor. It was not always so: before the second world war, Berlin was an industrial hub. But when the allies divided the city, many firms moved their offices and factories to West Germany. Berlin instead became a left-wing hub, attracting bohemians and anti-capitalists. As more tech start-ups move into the city, its economic fortunes could change, but it remains dysfunctional.

10.  What is the Nash equilibrium and why does it matter? | September 2016

Another of the year’s most popular explainers was written in earlier times. In 2016 we explained the Nash equilibrium, named after John Nash, who won a Nobel prize in 1994 for his contribution to economics. In a Nash equilibrium, every person in a group makes the best decision for herself, based on what she thinks the others will do. The theory helps economists work out how competing companies set their prices, how governments should design auctions to squeeze the most from bidders and how to explain the sometimes self-defeating decisions that groups make.
